Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Decentralized Telephonic Triage System for Charitable Clinic COVID-19 Crisis Response

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to COVID-19, the demand on charitable clinics, the nationâ€™s health care safety net, is now greater than ever, and additional capabilities are needed to help combat the impact of the pandemic on their communities. But unlike hospital systems and large clinical networks, charitable clinics lack the human or technological infrastructure to manage the tremendous demand, specifically the increased volume of telephonic requests for information, referrals, clinical care related to COVID-19, and clinical care unrelated but impacted by COVID-19. The influx of patient calls has led to unnecessary high-risk visits to the clinic for issues appropriate for telemedicine, and increased emergency room utilization due to clinic overload. In addition to exposure risk, health and financial outcomes are impacted when staff cannot appropriately triage and manage telephonic requests. The goal of this research is to assess the efficacy and feasibility of an innovative technology tool, HelplineSOS, to offer a decentralized telephonic triage solution so that charitable clinics can rapidly answer non-emergency calls related to COVID-19. The project will be conducted by Sostento Inc., a 501c3 nonprofit whose mission is to help organizations on the frontline of public health emergencies in ways that will save more lives, with the support of a local research manager and experts with specialization in telephonic triage systems.

The critical research questions of this project are 1) to explore the ability for the technology to produce the patient and system behavioral outcomes (reduce high risk clinic visit, burden staff with questions better answered elsewhere, and triaging away from ERs), and 2) to determine the acceptability and adoptability of a new technology such as this. The research follows a successful pilot and proof of concept deployment of HelplineSOS. The Georgia Charitable Care Network, a charitable clinic network, has identified additional clinics to adopt the tool and participate in a study to determine efficacy of the technology and feasibility for a state-wide deployment. It is expected that project outcomes will enable approaches that mitigate the negative effects of COVID-19 on public health, society, and the economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 novel coronavirus (COVID-19) created a significant burden on health systems both nationally and globally. Among the first substantial demands felt by safety-net health clinics was an increase in call volume from communities seeking information and requesting health services. The rapid response research sought to measure the efficacy and feasibility of an innovative technology tool, HelplineSOS. 

HelplineSOS is a computer and phone-based technology that allows remote staff and volunteers to respond to high volumes of COVID-19 related telephone calls into safety-net clinics. The system's interactive voice response (IVR) technology and database system automatically triages incoming calls by urgency. The callers are then organized into a collaborative, secure cloud-based platform for callback by a distributed team of volunteers and/or staff working from the safety of home.

During HelplineSOS calls, volunteers/staff utilize a predefined script for non-emergency COVID-19 inquiries, offering patients up-to-date information on guidelines, reassurance, and routing to appropriate escalation needs. HelplineSOS volunteer clinicians offer evidence-based clinical guidance to route patients towards low-risk interventions that prevent unnecessary in-person contact and possible COVID-19 exposure. 

This study utilized a mixed methods approach, gathering quantitative data from patient calls and soliciting qualitative feedback from clinic leadership and implementers to answer the following research questions: (1) What is the feasibility for the technology to produce patient and systems behavioral outcomes (reducing high risk clinic visits, reducing burden on staff with questions better answered elsewhere, and triaging away from ERs) and (2) What is the acceptability and adoptability of HelplineSOS?

The results of the research emphatically confirmed HelplineSOS as a feasible tool for safety-net clinics to rapidly adopt and receive immediate relief in answering a large volume of calls.  Clinic staff, particularly providers, saved valuable time by not having to listen to voicemails and instead could rely on HelplineSOS to intake all relevant information needed for callbacks. Without HelplineSOS, clinic leadership believed that they would not have been able to manage their own clinic patient call volume, much less the additional rates  they were seeing come in from non-clinic patients. 

Data related to HelplineSOS deployment was collected via clinic focus groups and leadership interviews at baseline and post-implementation at three safety net clinics. Participating clinics were based in Atlanta, Georgia; Minneapolis, Minnesota; and Fort Worth, Texas. The implementation process for HelplineSOS in the three research clinics is comprehensive both in didactic training and reference materials, but in quality assurance and structure that allows for consistent stakeholder feedback. The creation of an outcomes dashboard, available to stakeholders, serves both as a check of rigor and a QAPI tool so that continuous improvement is not only possible, but a standard of practice. 

Following implementation, clinics saw an increase in their capacity to service and address community callers. For example, they were able to respond to triple the call volume without having to hire additional staff, and callers were able to receive a same day call back. Clinics remarked that alongside the rapid onboarding, the system was flexible, sophisticated yet simple, and user-friendly. The HelplineSOS system allowed each clinic to use a common intake flow but  could then differentiate and prioritize the callers based on their various needs and capabilities.  Volunteers emphasized the ease and simplicity of managing the calls facilitated with HelplineSOS. Those volunteers, motivated by the pandemic and the value of their work, served as key implementers of the protocols that maximized patient care through the telephonic intervention. 

In addition to successfully reaching a high number of patient callers with rapid turnaround, HelplineSOS allowed clinics to quickly divert routine care needs to telehealth. Through rigorous and standardized escalation protocols, testing capacity, and tracking of patient needs, HelplineSOS increased safety during COVID-19 by maximizing digital health resources. In interviews with clinics, senior leadership recognized they were part of the core response; pioneers amidst a time of lack of tests, confusion, and fragmented services. The comprehensive protocol and training for HelplineSOS stakeholders and volunteers ensured that care was efficiently and consistently escalated when patients required diversion to telehealth or emergency services. Although the percentage of callers requiring emergency intervention was low, the adoption of HelplineSOS ensured that all symptomatic patients were offered a telehealth visit. Clinics also reported linking callers to testing at the clinic and through other local testing sites helping to relieve the burden on local urgent care clinics and emergency rooms given most of their callers are underinsured or uninsured. 

Since it was  launched in March 2020, HelplineSOS has been utilized to respond to over 75,000 COVID-19 calls at 25 clinics covering 10 states across the US.  For more information visit www.helplinesos.org.
